title: 106_hr1659
content: The "National Police Training Commission Act of 1999" establishes the National Police Training Commission, subject to appropriations, with defined membership. The National Police Training Commission, established by the "National Police Training Commission Act of 1999," consists of 5 members appointed by Senate and House leaders. Members must have knowledge or expertise in relevant matters and can be from various sectors. The National Police Training Commission, established by the "National Police Training Commission Act of 1999," consists of 5 members appointed by Senate and House leaders. Members must have relevant backgrounds in civil and criminal litigation, law enforcement, administrative functions, management, and community relations. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, which will cease to exist 1 year after the initial appointment of the 4 members. The National Police Training Commission consists of 5 members appointed by Senate and House leaders with backgrounds in various fields. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission meets at the call of the Chairperson who is elected by the members. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS. The Commission will study the effectiveness of training, recruiting, hiring, oversight, and funding policies in law enforcement, including training in use of force, non-lethal force, tactical strategies, cultural diversity, community relations, and recruitment standards for law enforcement officers. The Commission will study hiring standards, oversight procedures, and funding effectiveness for law enforcement programs, including training, diversity, complaint procedures, due process, discrimination, and funding allocation. The Commission established under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of its appointment, detailing the results of its study on law enforcement programs and making recommendations on best practices. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Commission can obtain necessary information from Federal agencies. Members serve without compensation, and travel expenses are covered while on Commission business. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation should not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Other personnel's compensation can be determined by the Chairman without following specific regulations. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint personnel without following civil service laws, and their compensation should not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and the Chairman can procure temporary services under specific regulations. The Commission shall meet at the Chairman's call, with a quorum of two members needed for business. Each member has one vote of equal weight, and rules can be established by majority vote. Information acquired is for research purposes only and kept confidential as deemed necessary by the Commission. The Commission determines confidential information, such as law enforcement officers' identities, shall not be disclosed publicly or included in any reports. The Commission is considered a Federal agency, and its members are government employees for specific legal purposes. The Commission may conduct hearings, administer oaths, and act as needed. The Commission may conduct hearings, administer oaths, and receive evidence as necessary to fulfill its duties under section 4. Witnesses appearing before the Commission will be paid fees as per section 1821 of title 28, United States Code, from funds allocated to the Commission. SEC. 6. TRAINING. Section 210501 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to provide training, recruitment, hiring, and oversight assistance to specific cities and police departments across the country. The National Police Training Commission provides funding assistance for equipment to cities and police departments based on their size. The assistance is distributed proportionally, and $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000. SEC. 7. DATA ON DEATHS WHILE IN CUSTODY. Section 20101(b) of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to include guidelines for reporting information on deaths of individuals in custody, including details like name, gender, ethnicity, age, date, time, and location of death. The amended guidelines require reporting details of deceased individuals in custody, including the date, time, and location of death, along with a brief description of the circumstances surrounding the death.
